FIGREF0.text: Fibroblastic foci and b cystic remodeling of lung lobules (microscopic equivalent of honeycombing). Note the transformation of epithelia into a bronchiolar type. H&E; bar, 0.1 and 0.2 mm

FIGREF1.text: Fig. 3 EMT in a fibroblastic focus: Immunohistochemistry using double stain for TTF1 (brown, nuclear) and smooth muscle actin (red, cytoplasmic) in the same cells. Magnification, ×200

FIGREF2.text: Cellular NSIP; note the well-preserved lung architecture, only the alveolar septa are widened by the inflammatory infiltrate. H&E; bar, 100 μm

FIGREF3.text: Fibrotic NSIP; even in this fibrotic lesion, the architecture with the alveolar walls can be discerned. H&E; magnification, ×100Fig. 7Granulation tissue within an alveolus, so-called Masson body (OP). Note the inflammatory infiltrate and also a blood vessel within the granulation tissue. H&E; bar, 50 μm

FIGREF4.text: Late stage of OP: granulation tissue plugs are covered by regenerating epithelium, a slit-like space of the original alveolus remained. H&E; magnification, ×200

FIGREF5.text: DAD in viral infection; besides hyaline membranes, there are scattered atypical pneumocytes with viral inclusion bodies (arrows). H&E; magnification, ×400

FIGREF6.text: LIP, lymphoepithelial lesion, here in a case of SjS; note the aggressive lymphocytic infiltration with destruction of the epithelium. H&E; magnification, ×200

FIGREF7.text: LIP, late stage with destruction of the lung architecture. Here in a case of immunodeficiency in a 3-year-old child. H&E; magnification, ×100

FIGREF8.text: rhA with a combination of IP patterns: UIP and LIP in this case. Note the fibroblastic foci; in contrast to IPF, the lymphocytic infiltration is mixed with the myofibroblast proliferation. H&E; bar, 0.05 mm

FIGREF9.text: rhA with lung involvement; here formation of a histiocytic granuloma, similar what is found in affected joints; polarized light helps to highlight remnants of collagen fibers within the necrotic center. H&E; bar, 20 μm

FIGREF10.text: Mixed UIP and NSIP pattern in a case of SSc. H&E; bar, 0.1 mm

FIGREF11.text: Vasculopathy in SSc; note the eccentric thickening of the arterial wall and pseudomyxoid changes. H&E; magnification, ×100

FIGREF12.text: Older lesion in a case of Goodpasture's disease showing hemosiderin-laden macrophages and recent hemorrhage. In addition, lymphocytic and histiocytic inflammatory infiltrates are seen. H&E; bar, 50 μm

FIGREF13.text: Typical distribution pattern of fibrosis and muscular cirrhosis in a case of ACIF. The involvement is strictly confined to a lobular structure and follows the bronchial tree from the larger bronchus to the small bronchioles. H&E; bar, 0.2 mm

FIGREF14.text: LHCH; note the complete destruction of the bronchial wall (center) by the proliferation of Langerhans cells and infiltrating eosinophils. Remnants of smooth muscle cells can be seen. The pulmonary artery is nearby. H&E; bar, 50 μm

FIGREF15.text: RBILD; recognize the accumulation of pigmented smokers macrophages in the bronchioles and the adjacent centroacinar region. H&E; bar, 0.1 mm

FIGREF16.text: SRIF and RB in a patient with clinical severe COPD; here, an area with emphysema and fibroblastic focus is shown. H&E; bar, 0.2 mm

FIGREF17.text: Alveolar lipoproteinosis in an adult (a) with proven autoantibodies for GMCSF and in a 19-year-old male patient (b) with severe fibrosis of alveolar septa; he died after many recurrences of alveolar lipoproteinosis. H&E; magnification, ×100

FIGREF18.text: Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome in a child. Note the accumulation of foamy macrophage giant cells within alveoli, proliferation of pneumocytes type II, many fibroblastic foci, and severe fibrosis. H&E; bar, 50 μm

FIGREF19.text: DPB in a 5-year-old child. The characteristic features are a follicular bronchiolitis and BALT hyperplasia. H&E; magnification, ×150

FIGREF20.text: Metastatic pulmonary calcification in a patient with secondary hyperparathyroidism (renal failure and hyperplasia of two parathyroid glands and clinical hypercalcemia). Note the sponge-like calcium deposits within the alveolar walls, almost outlining the septa. H&E; bar, 0.05 mm

FIGREF21.text: Microlithiasis; note the lamellated bodies within alveoli and alveolar septa, accompanied by a macrophage reaction with many foreign body giant cells. H&E; bar, 50 μm

TABREF0.text: CRP diagnoses and their morphologic counterparts

TABREF2.text: Probable not IPF, when CT and pathology show features not compatible with IPF, & Definite not IPF, if there are features of other interstitial diseases [10].

TABREF3.text: If fibrosis is present, this usually causes no distortion of the lung architecture. & Fibrosis is diffuse, not merging with scars. Inflammatory infiltrates in cases of fibrosing NSIP are usually scarce. & Non-necrotizing granulomas can be present in certain cases (EAA), however, should not be encountered in idiopathic NSIP. & Hyperplasia of BALT is absent.
